dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Welcome back to the podcast! So, you know, it's been a pretty wild week in the markets, right? Despite, like, everything going on with the coronavirus, stocks are, uh, soaring. It's kind of counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Welcome back to the podcast! So, you know, it's been a pretty wild week in the markets, right? Despite, like, everything going on with the coronavirus, stocks are, uh, soaring. It's kind of counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All three major indexes are off to a rough start this week after recording their worst losses in months on Monday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's completely wild. We're seeing record-breaking profits for some companies, but then, like, others are reporting these massive losses, yet the market, overall, seems to be celebrating this financial boom from the virus.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's completely wild. We're seeing record-breaking profits for some companies, but then, like, others are reporting these massive losses, yet the market, overall, seems to be celebrating this financial boom from the virus.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its a big week for the market with a host of major companies set to report earnings as stocks pare back from near-record highs on rising concerns over the severity and economic impact of the deadly Chinese coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know! That's what I don't get. How can it be a "financial boom" when we're talking about a deadly virus?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! That's what I don't get. How can it be a financial boom when we're talking about a deadly virus?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, um, the article points out that it's actually acting as a bit of a tailwind. Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge says that the market's trading at sustainable valuations, and investors are just kind of embracing it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, um, the article points out that it's actually acting as a bit of a tailwind. Adam Crisafulli from Vital Knowledge says that the market's trading at sustainable valuations, and investors are just kind of embracing it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Making things even riskier for investors is a market thats trading at unsustainable valuations, according to Adam Crisafulli, founder of Vital Knowledge, who says that the coronavirus is acting as an added headwind at a time when stocks are becoming extraordinarily sensitive to even the smallest setbacks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A tailwind? So the coronavirus is, like, *helping* stocks?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A tailwind? So the coronavirus is, like, helping stocks?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Apparently! The thinking is that the virus is "disappearing," with a vaccine already available, so it's having a positive impact on consumer demand and tourism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apparently! The thinking is that the virus is disappearing, with a vaccine already available, so it's having a positive impact on consumer demand and tourism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Chinas coronavirus is playing a huge role in the direction of stocks as the disease rapidly spreads with no vaccine in sight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Disappearing, though? That seems, um, a little premature, maybe?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Disappearing, though? That seems, um, a little premature, maybe?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but that's the perception driving the market right now. And, like, US companies in China are reportedly exempt from pain, some have even reopened stores.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but that's the perception driving the market right now. And, like, U S companies in China are reportedly exempt from pain, some have even reopened stores.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. companies with businesses in China are not exempt from the pain as some have already closed stores in the region.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, who's actually feeling this positive impact?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, who's actually feeling this positive impact?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Hotels, airlines, cruise operators, big retailers, consumer goods companiesâ€”they're all seeing a boost.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hotels, airlines, cruise operators, big retailers, consumer goods companies-they're all seeing a boost.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hotels, airlines, cruise and casino operators, big retailers and consumer goods companies have all so far been affected by the financial impact of the coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the numbers are really backing this up, aren't they? Like, the major indexes are having a fantastic week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the numbers are really backing this up, aren't they? Like, the major indexes are having a fantastic week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: All three major indexes are off to a rough start this week after recording their worst losses in months on Monday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. S&P 500 up 1.6%, Nasdaq 1.9%, the Dow 1.5%. [interrupts] These are their best gains in months!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. S and P five hundred up one point six percent, Nasdaq one point nine percent, the Dow one point five percent. These are their best gains in months!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The S&P 500 was down 1.6%, the Nasdaq Composite index 1.9% and the Dow Jones industrial average 1.5%. It was the Dows worst single-day drop since October 2, 2019, the S&Ps since October 8, 2019, and the Nasdaqs since August 23, 2019, according to Dow Jones Market Data.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is just crazy when you look at it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is just crazy when you look at it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. Even crude oil prices hit a three-month high. Amazon's expecting 86 billion in sales, Tesla over 7 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. Even crude oil prices hit a three-month high. Amazon's expecting eighty six billion in sales, Tesla over seven billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Crude oil prices also hit a three-month low on Monday, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate falling to $53 per barrel.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what could possibly spoil all this optimism in 2020? Because the article hints at something.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what could possibly spoil all this optimism in twenty twenty? Because the article hints at something.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's the kicker! Chris Zaccarelli, uh, compares it to the SARS outbreak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's the kicker! Chris Zaccarelli, uh, compares it to the S A R S outbreak.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zaccarelli compares the coronavirus with the SARS outbreak

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, SARS. Right. What happened back then?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, S A R S. Right. What happened back then?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the S&P 500 dropped 12% over five months, but then, like, finished that year 19% higher. Investors are just taking a 'buy first, ask questions later' approach.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the S and P five hundred dropped twelve percent over five months, but then, like, finished that year nineteen percent higher. Investors are just taking a buy first, ask questions later approach.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although historically these outbreaks have been buying opportunities, the bottom line is investors are taking a sell first and ask questions later approach right now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's all about that quick short-term gain right now. Wild stuff.
